Subduction zones contracted. Volcanic emissions dropped from 30 million tons a year to 10 million tons. Less volcanic carbon dioxide heating the air cooled the planet. The construction of continental shelves created gigantic, shallow seas.

Even with pledges made under the Glasgow climate pact to double adaptation finance to $40 billion by 2025, UNEP said the target will likely be missed if current trends continue. articles.author: The Independent
articles.summary: The Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA) and Mathematica Global held a validation workshop on climate vulnerability mapping and climate change risk analysis in Entebbe, Uganda. The study is part of a five-country initiative covering Uganda, Kenya, Tanzania, Ghana and Zambia. It aims to provide evidence-based insights into how vulnerable different farming areas are to climate shocks.

articles.title: Mount Merapi, Indonesia's most active volcano, erupts
articles.author: Jay Hilotin
articles.summary: Mount Merapi, Indonesia's most active volcano, erupted on October 29, 2025, sending plumes of ash and smoke into the sky. The volcano's status remains at level 4, signifying a high risk of further eruptions, prompting ongoing monitoring and preparedness by local authorities.

articles.title: Nagai fishermen resumes fishing after 11 days
articles.author: NT Bureau
articles.summary: Fishermen in Nagapattinam have been banned from fishing for 11 days due to the cyclone Moonda. About 700 country boats and 3,000 fiber boats were not allowed to go to sea. The cyclone has moved away and the warning flag has been lowered. Fishermen are optimistic about their catch.

articles.title: What WILL lead to humanity's demise? As Bill Gates says it won't be climate change, experts reveal the bleak reality of our extinction
articles.author: WILIAM HUNTER
articles.summary: In an open letter ahead of the UN COP30 climate summit in Brazil, Bill Gates wrote that climate change is not the biggest threat to humanity. According to experts, humanity is more likely to annihilate itself before the worst effects of climate change are felt. The biggest threat of all is the looming danger of total nuclear war, according to Dr Rhys Crilley.

articles.title: Courts Are Shaping the Future of Climate Action
articles.author: Francesca Mascha Klein
articles.summary: In the absence of political will, the law has become a crucial driver of climate progress. Recent rulings make it clear that countries have binding legal duties to cut emissions, phase out fossil fuels, and finance adaptation efforts. Last year was the hottest on record, with global average temperatures exceeding 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: How climate change is making us sick
articles.author: Deutsche Welle
articles.summary: The Lancet Countdown Report warns that climate change is threatening human health. Last year was the warmest on record and CO2 levels in the atmosphere jumped to new highs. Heat-related deaths have surged 23% since the 1990s, with rising temperatures claiming over half a million lives every year. Wildfire smoke was linked to a record 154,000 deaths in 2024, while air pollution from the burning of fossil fuels kills 2.5 million people each year. In 2024, there was a record number of dengue infections worldwide, with more than 7.6 million cases. Extreme weather events cost hundreds of billions of dollars annually.

articles.title: Australian Marine Environments Face Shock 2040 Deadline
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Even Australia's most protected marine habitats are likely to suffer extreme ocean impacts by 2040, increasing threats to plant and animal species. Marine Protected Areas off north-western and eastern Australia are the most vulnerable. The team calls for urgent action on reducing carbon emissions to delay or partly limit the projected climate impacts.

articles.title: Cyclone Montha destroys paddy crops, worsens woes of farmers in Odisha
articles.author: Subhaswapna Roul
articles.summary: Cyclone Montha has damaged the livelihoods of farmers in Dharakote, Ganjam district. Three days of relentless rain and gusty winds have inundated acres of farmland, turning once lush green fields into muddy wastelands. The farmers are trying to salvage whatever little they can from their damaged crops.

articles.title: Photos: Hurricane Melissa swamps Cuba
articles.author: C. A. Bridges
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is churning towards Cuba after making landfall in Jamaica in Santiago de Cuba, Cuba October 28, 2025. Susana Arencibia cooks with charcoal on the balcony of her home. Patrice Noel uses a plastic sheet to protect himself from the rain.

articles.title: Why Hurricane Melissa is one of the strongest Atlantic storms ever
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: The monster hurricane pummelling Jamaica is powered by abnormal sea surface temperatures in the Caribbean made 500 times more likely by global warming, according to the UN.    .   - Global warming is to blame for the increase in sea surface temperature in the region.

articles.title: Fury of Hurricane Melissa Unleashes Havoc in the Caribbean
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Melissa is the most powerful hurricane ever recorded in the Caribbean. It hit Cuba's southern coast on Wednesday, bringing winds of 120 mph. In Jamaica, over 500,000 people were left without power, but there were no confirmed deaths. Authorities attribute the intensifying nature of hurricanes to climate change. Cuba has begun recovery efforts.

articles.title: Arabian Sea Depression moves northeast, 810Km distance from Karachi
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: The Arabian Sea Depression over east-central Arabian Sea moved northeastwards during past 24 hours and is now located 810 km southeast of Karachi and 430 km southwest of Veraval, Gujarat (India). There is no threat to any Pakistani coastal area. In the beginning of October, a low-pressure over the Arabian Sea was intensified into Depression and located 440 km south from Karachi causing high waves and rough weather in the sea along Sindh's coastal belt.

articles.title: Climate Change Causing More Deaths From Heat, Wildfire Smoke
articles.author: Dennis Thompson
articles.summary: The rate of heat-related deaths has risen by 23% since the 1990s and now claim 546,000 lives each year. 154,000 deaths occurred due to air pollution from wildfire smoke in 2024 alone. 2.5 million deaths a year are attributable to the air pollution created from the burning of fossil fuels like gasoline and coal.

articles.title: Climate change means prioritising preparation
articles.author: Ricardo Smith
articles.summary: Climate change in the Caribbean has never been more evident. Jamaica is bracing itself for a major hurricane at the end of the hurricane season. There is an urgent need to raise awareness and educate communities about the impact of climate change. People living in vulnerable areas should prioritise evacuation before disaster strikes and take time to assess situation upon returning home.

articles.title: Climate Inaction Is Killing Millions: Lancet-WHO Report Calls for Health-Focused Climate Action
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The 2025 Lancet Countdown on Health and Climate Change was released in partnership with the World Health Organization (WHO). The report makes a compelling case for placing health at the heart of climate strategies ahead of COP30 in Belém, Brazil. Global governments spent US$ 956 billion on fossil fuel subsidies in 2023. Renewable sources supply 12% of global electricity, creating 16 million jobs and reducing emissions at scale.

articles.title: Melissa's foreboding path and our response
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa has devastated Jamaica, Cuba and Turks and Caicos Islands. Cuba's south-eastern provinces are at risk of flooding and damage. The Caribbean sister nations are bracing for the storm's impact. The international community needs to act quickly in three key ways for all three countries.

articles.title: 6-million-year-old Antarctic ice offers window to ancient Earth
articles.author: Mrigakshi Dixit
articles.summary: Scientists have found a six-million-year-old ice sample from the Allan Hills region of East Antarctica. The discovery comes from the drilling of ice cores in Allan Hill. The ancient ice dates back to a geological era with abundant proof of warmer conditions and higher sea levels compared to modern times. It's the first direct measure of Antarctica's long-term cooling trend.

articles.title: Robins will keep coming back to your garden if you feed them 1 food in November
articles.author: Steffan Rhys
articles.summary: During autumn, birds become quieter and their presence is less noticeable. The RSPB recommends feeding birds high-energy, high-fat foods during cold weather. It's also important to clean bird baths regularly and keep the garden clean to prevent disease spread.

articles.title: Long summers mean less of China's prized hairy crabs
articles.author: Brian Mikael Cheng
articles.summary: China's hairy crabs, otherwise known as mitten crabs, have had their breeding and growth cycle disrupted by warmer waters. Crabs farmers are worried that future catches may continue to shrink if the crabs don't adapt to warmer weather soon. The crabs normally mature by autumn.

articles.title: Global emissions to fall in the next decade, UN reports
articles.author: Elizaveta Vereykina
articles.summary: China, the United States, India, the EU27, Russia and Indonesia are the biggest greenhouse gas emitters in the world in 2024. According to the latest UN report, only 64 countries have made new commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 2025. The Paris climate agreement required all countries to do so. The UN has registered a positive forecast of declining emissions for the first time since 1990.

articles.title: Australia goes Shark Smart; uses drones and apps to keep swimmers safe
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: Rising sea temperatures, more people in the water and shifts in fish stocks may be driving an increase in shark attacks in Australia. Since records began in 1791, Australia has logged more than 1,280 shark incidents, 260 of them fatal. The past 25 years have seen 56 deaths, more than double the previous quarter-century's tally.

articles.title: Explained in Graphics: What happens if humanity missed the 1.5°C climate target
articles.summary: Ten years after the Paris climate pact, it's inevitable that the 1.5°C limit will be breached. The 2015 Paris Agreement set a target to limit surface temperature to well below 2°Celsius. The UN General Secretary Antonio Guterres warned that the world must change course immediately.

articles.title: Adapting to an already changed climate
articles.author: Equans Uk
articles.summary: Floods, droughts and heatwaves are no longer rare events. The UK must prepare itself for extreme weather impacts resulting from temperatures spiralling beyond 2C above pre-industrial levels. James Heritage, climate risk, adaptation and resilience manager at Equans UK & Ireland, believes adaptation begins with robust data.

articles.title: Coastal Erosion Claims Four Additional Beachfront Homes in North Carolina
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: The Atlantic Ocean destroyed four vacation homes near Buxton on the Outer Banks on Tuesday morning. Since 2020, Hatteras Island has witnessed the ocean swallowing 26 homes, with two additional properties intentionally demolished due to environmental threats. The Outer Banks, a chain of islands that includes Buxton, has faced repeated disasters, most recently when five homes disintegrated within a single hour. The shoreline moved inland by 675 feet between 1980 and 2020. The coastal haven is fragile because of its geography and small size.

articles.title: Climate Change Heats Up Himachal Pradesh, Raises Alarm For Future: UNDP Report
articles.author: ETV Bharat
articles.summary: Himachal Pradesh has warmed by 1.5 degrees Celsius since 1901. The average temperature is projected to rise by 2 to 3 degrees Celsius by 2050. The state has already suffered nearly Rs 46,000 crore of economic losses due to heavy rainfall, landslides, and related disasters. The number of forest fires rose sharply to 2,580 cases in 2024-25, compared with 856 incidents in 2022-23. 70% of traditional water sources are under threat due to climate change, affecting agriculture, construction and tourism.

articles.title: Cuba Mobilizes Agriculture Sector as Hurricane Melissa Hits
articles.summary: Cuba's Ministry of Agriculture ordered emergency measures on Tuesday for farms in the Guantánamo to Camagüey regions to protect food supplies, livestock and infrastructure as Hurricane Melissa makes landfall today (October 29). The emergency measures include moving animals from low-lying areas, safeguarding feed, fertilizers and pesticides, harvesting at-risk crops, and protecting tobacco production, and beehives. Authorities will prioritize water, food, and primary health care access, and maintain milk collection and distribution. Drones will be used for reconnaissance in low-visibility or hard-to-reach areas.

articles.title: COP30 To Focus On Limiting Warming, Climate Finance
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: Key issues for COP30 are limiting global temperature rise to 1.5°C, climate finance commitments, and the impacts of climate change on vulnerable populations.       "COP30" is an international conference taking place in COP30 in Bonn.

articles.title: Climate inaction causing 'millions' of avoidable deaths
articles.author: Naharnet
articles.summary: Climate change is ravaging the health of people around the world. Policy failures are leading to "millions" of avoidable deaths each year, according to the UNFPA. The world needs to act now to prevent millions of deaths every year from climate change-related illnesses.

articles.title: CORRECTION: Public Concern for Climate Change Shows Sharp Decline in Kenya and South Africa in 2025
articles.author: APO
articles.summary: The Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) reports a decline in public concern for climate change in Kenya and South Africa even after the hottest year on record. The 2025 Global Consumer Awareness Survey was conducted with IPSOS across 50 countries and found that people are less concerned about climate change.

articles.title: Gates: Shift climate focus to easing human suffering
articles.author: Jennifer Mcdermott
articles.summary: Bill Gates thinks climate change is a serious problem, but it won't be the end of civilization. He thinks it's not going to be a big problem either, however, and it's unlikely to end the world as we know it, either.

articles.title: AP CM Chandrababu conducts aerial inspection of cyclone Montha-affected areas
articles.author: Pavan Bandari
articles.summary: Andhra Pradesh Chief Minister N. Chandrababu Naidu is flying over flooded areas in Bapatla, Palnadu, Krishna, Eluru, and Dr. BR Ambedkar Konaseema districts to assess the extent of Cyclone Mondha's devastation. He is also visiting Allavaram mandal's port in Konasesema district to inspect the inundated crop fields.

articles.title: Heat from climate crisis now killing one person every minute, global report reveals
articles.author: Newsroom
articles.summary: Rising global temperatures are now killing one person every minute worldwide. Global warming is also causing toxic air pollution, wildfires, and the spread of diseases such as dengue fever. Governments provided £723 billion in direct fossil fuel subsidies in 2023, the same amount people lost due to high temperatures preventing them from working on farms and building sites. Fifteen countries, including Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Venezuela, and Algeria, spent more on Fossil Fuels than on their national health budgets.

articles.title: GCC advances joint climate action at the Meteorology Committee Meeting
articles.author: arabtimes
articles.summary: The 17th meeting of the Permanent Committee for Meteorology and Climate of the Gulf Cooperation Council took place in Kuwait. Duaij Al-Otaibi, the acting director general of the Public Authority for Civil Aviation, chaired the session. He praised the establishment of an advanced early warning network for weather and climate disasters across GCC countries and the adoption of a unified meteorology law.

articles.title: Bill Gates makes major climate change reversal after years of doomerism: ‘People will be able ...
articles.author: New York Post
articles.summary: Bill Gates has spent more than a decade warning that the world was on the brink of unimaginable peril due to rising global temperatures. He now says climate change 'will not lead to humanity's demise' in a stunning change of heart. He says it's not going to happen.

articles.title: Over half a million people are dying every year due to rising heat globally
articles.author: Jane Moore
articles.summary: There are more than half a million people dying every year due to heat-related causes due to climate change. Babies and older adults are facing over 20 heatwave days per person, a fourfold increase over the last twenty years. Last year had a record 154,000 deaths from pollution caused by wildfire smoke. Government provided $956 billion in fossil fuel subsidies in 2023, down from $1.4 trillion allocated the year before.

articles.title: The Arctic and Antarctica record "off the charts" heat as polar warming accelerates
articles.author: Ben Aris in Berlin
articles.summary: Vostok research station in central East Antarctica recorded a maximum temperature of –30.8°C on October 27. The previous record was –32.2°C. Concordia Station also reported an October temperature record of –28.9°C, according to climatologists tracking polar anomalies. The Antarctic heat coincides with similarly abnormal warmth in the Arctic.

articles.title: Climate Change Is One Of The Biggest Health Threats Worldwide: Lancet Report
articles.author: NDTV Health Desk
articles.summary: The 2025 Lancet Countdown report on Health and Climate Change has revealed alarming data highlighting the implications of climate change on human existence. Heat-related mortality has increased by 63% since the 1990s, and in India, an average of 20 heatwave days were observed in 2024. Household air pollution from the burning of fossil fuels kills 2.5 million people every year.

articles.title: Earth just surprised scientists! Extinction rate among plant and animal species has surprisingly slowed down
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: The global loss of species has long been seen as one of the greatest threats to life on Earth. For decades, scientists have warned that human activity is pushing plants and animals towards extinction faster than they can recover, which is a problem for the environment.

articles.title: Special Advisory: Hurricane Melissa hits Cuba
articles.author: NC Hurricane Bot
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa has just made landfall in Cuba. The public is advised to follow the guidance issued by local authorities and emergency response agencies. Regular advisory will resume shortly. The advisory has been published on Wednesday, Oct 29th.  This story was originally published on October 28th.

articles.title: How one neighborhood reduced its carbon emissions by 1,600 metric tons
articles.author: Kristoffer Tigue
articles.summary: Mary Britton is a financial analyst living in Minneapolis. She saw images of huge wildfires in Spain and Australia in the summer of 2019. The fires were made worse by climate change, studies showed. Britton reduced her own carbon footprint to cope with the situation.

articles.title: Earth just surprised scientists! Extinction rate among plant and animal species has surprisingly slowed down
articles.author: TOI Science Desk
articles.summary: The extinction rate of plants and animals has slowed down in the last century. This does not mean that biodiversity loss has stopped, but the rate of disappearance has become less intense than expected. Global awareness and conservation efforts are helping to slow down the extinction rate. Many species remain critically endangered, and others could vanish before they are even documented.

articles.title: 1.72 million Indians died from air pollution in 2022: Report
articles.author: Sahil Sinha
articles.summary: In 2022, 1.72 million deaths in India were linked to air pollution, a 38 per cent jump since 2010, according to the 2025 Global Report of the Lancet Countdown on Health and Climate Change. In 2024, India endured an average of 19.8 heatwave days, 6.6 of which would not have occurred without human-driven climate change. The country lost 247 billion potential labour hours, translating to income losses worth USD 194 billion.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa: Chaos in the Caribbean
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Melissa has been downgraded to a Category 3 hurricane. The storm destroyed Jamaica with winds reaching 185 mph, leaving entire communities and infrastructure in ruins. 500,000 people in Cuba were ordered to evacuate. The Bahamas is bracing itself for the impact of Hurricane Melissa. Dominican Republic and Haiti are dealing with heavy rains.

articles.title: Climate Change Drives 23% Rise in Heat-Related Deaths, Lancet Report Warns
articles.summary: Heat-related deaths have increased by 23% since the 1990s. In 2024, air pollution from wildfire smoke contributed to a record 154,000 deaths, according to the Lancet Countdown Report on Health and Climate Change. 13 of 20 health indicators are at unprecedented levels.

articles.title: How Is Cyclone Montha Impacting Weather In Maharashtra? IMD Issues Heavy Rains, Thunderstorm Across State For Next 48 Hours
articles.author: Manasi Kamble
articles.summary: Cyclone Montha has made landfall along the Andhra Pradesh coast on Tuesday morning. The cyclone's indirect impact is expected to be felt in parts of Maharashtra over the next two days, including Pune, Mumbai, Gadchiroli, Gondia, Chandrapur, Bhandara and Nagpur.

articles.title: Climate inaction claiming millions of lives annually, warns new Lancet-WHO report
articles.summary: WHO and The Lancet warn that climate change is claiming millions of lives each year and threatening global health, economies, and livelihoods. They call for urgent recognition of health as the most powerful driver of climate action. The report found that 12 of 20 key indicators tracking health threats have reached record levels, highlighting how overreliance on fossil fuels and failure to adapt to a warming planet are taking a devastating toll on human health.

articles.title: Climate Change Fuelling Deadly Health Crisis Across the Globe, Report Finds
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: A new report shows that climate change is killing millions of people each year. The Lancet Countdown on Health and Climate Change highlights the health risks from fossil fuels, heatwaves, and pollution. Governments spent almost one trillion US dollars on fossil fuel subsidies in 2023 to keep prices low. However, clean air from reduced coal use saved 160,000 lives each year and renewable energy generation reached new highs.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa makes landfall in southern coast of eastern Cuba as an extremely dangerous Category 3 major hurricane.
articles.author: CGTN
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa makes landfall in southern coast of eastern Cuba as a Category 3 major hurricane and is extremely dangerous for people living in the area. It is expected to last for a few days.    for people in Cuba and for the rest of the world.

articles.title: "Climate inaction is claiming millions of lives every year"
articles.author: Newstalk Breakfast
articles.summary: According to the 2025 Lancet Countdown Report on Health and Climate Change, continued reliance on fossil fuels and insufficient adaptation to rising global temperatures are having serious consequences for human health. Ciara discussed this further with Sinead Loughran, Climate Policy Officer with Trócaire.

articles.title: Bill Gates Calls for Strategic Shift from Climate to Disease
articles.author: Africa
articles.summary: Bill Gates argues that global resources should be strategically shifted away from fighting climate change and toward fighting disease and hunger. The push for this redirection is driven, in part, by recent cuts to international aid. Critics argue that Gates is posing a false dichotomy.

articles.title: UN Launches Sea-Lift Aid for Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is making landfall in Jamaica as a category 5 storm. UN agencies are mobilising supplies to support affected communities. The World Food Programme is coordinating a sea-lift operation from Barbados. UNICEF has pre-positioned water, sanitation, and hygiene kits for about 14,500 people and nutritional supplies for more than 4,000 children. WHO-led Pan American Health Organization has provided medical kits for 11,000 people.

articles.title: Climate inaction causing 'millions' of avoidable deaths: study
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Lancet's Countdown is a major annual study tracking the health impacts of climate change. 546,000 people died each year between 2012 and 2021 because of exposure to heat, a massive increase on figures from the 1990s. Toxic fumes from wildfires killed a record 154,000 last year. Fossil fuel-related air pollution caused more than 2.5 million deaths in 2022 alone. Governments spent $950 billion on fossil fuel subsidies in 2023.

articles.title: The world is better off for Bill Gates, the climate debate may not be
articles.author: Nick O'Malley
articles.summary: As Hurricane Melissa made landfall in Jamaica, Bill Gates wrote a memo arguing that global warming is not the biggest threat to the lives and livelihoods of people in poor countries and won't be in the future. About 750,000 people in Jamaica – GDP per capita $US7486 ($11,335) – had been evacuated by the time the memo was published.

articles.title: The world is better off for Bill Gates, the climate debate may not be
articles.author: Nick O'Malley
articles.summary: As Hurricane Melissa made landfall in Jamaica, Bill Gates published a memo arguing that global warming is not the biggest threat to the lives and livelihoods of people in poor countries. About 750,000 people in Jamaica had been evacuated by the time the memo was being debated in climate circles.

articles.title: UN Chief: 'We will not be able to contain the global warming below 1.5 degrees in the next few years'
articles.author: Robin Millard
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres says it's impossible to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels in the short term, but it's possible before the end of the century. The 2015 Paris climate accords aimed to limit warming to well below 2C, and to cut CO2 emissions by 60% by 2035, from 2019 levels.

articles.title: Climate change won't end civilization — Bill Gates
articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.summary: Bill Gates has written a long memo on climate change. He argues that tackling global disease and poverty will help prepare the planet's poorest for a warming world. He is a major backer of green technologies through his Breakthrough Energy organization. The memo comes days ahead of the COP30 climate summit in Brazil.

articles.title: Climate change sees 23% rise in heat-related deaths since 1990's
articles.summary: Maria Walawender, Lancet Countdown Research Fellow on Climate Change and Health, outlines the findings of a new report which found that heat-related deaths caused by global warming has risen to almost 550,000 a year. She is concerned about the impact of climate change on human health.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa leaves trail of destruction across Jamaica
articles.summary: Pete Sankey is Senior associate editor of the Jamaica Observer. He talks about the impact of Hurricane Melissa in Jamaica and the damage caused by it.       i   in Jamaica.  in this article Pete Sankey talks about Hurricane Melissa.

articles.title: Drowning In Neglect: How Mismanagement And Climate Change Fuel Pakistan's Flood Crisis
articles.author: Nasir Ali Panhwar
articles.summary: Pakistan is facing its worst riverine flooding in decades. Since late June, 6.9 million people have been affected, including 4.7 million in Punjab, 1.6 million in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, 356,000 in Gilgit-Baltistan, and 185,000 people in Sindh. There is a need for sustainable climate-resilience strategies and proactive preparedness.

articles.title: Flash Flood warnings issued for AP and Telangana states amid rains
articles.author: Pavan Kumar Bandari
articles.summary: IMD issues warnings of imminent flash floods in Telugu states of Telangana and Andhra Pradesh. Heavy rainfall is expected to trigger flooding in these regions, along with parts of Maharashtra and Vidarbha. The coastal region of Yanam and the districts of Guntur and Prakasam are particularly at risk. In Maharashtra's Marathwada region, Nanded, Hingoli, and Parbani are expected to experience adverse weather conditions.

articles.title: Breakthrough Institute's Ted Nordhaus warns global warming is real, but the ‘catastrophism' pushed by activists misrepresents the science
articles.author: Conor Breslin
articles.summary: Ted Nordhaus is a leading environmentalist and the Breakthrough Institute Executive Director. He believes that the alarmist rhetoric about climate change is misleading the public and undermining sensible policy. Mr Nordhaus believes that while climate change can intensify some weather events, it is wrong to suggest it is responsible for creating natural disasters.

articles.title: THE ARGUMENT ON ARCTIC SEA ICE
articles.author: Robin Westenra
articles.summary: Thorsten Viddal has spent a couple of years monitoring Arctic sea ice. Sea ice during the melt season was very thin and mushy, even close to the North Pole. The turn of the century had 19,900 km³ of sea ice in the Arctic, whereas in 2024 it was only 13,600 km². The ice is declining faster since 2000 than it did before 2000.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa Devastates Jamaica, Moves Toward Cuba
articles.author: Itishree Sethy
articles.summary: Melissa is the most powerful storm ever recorded in Jamaica. It submerged the parish of St. Elizabeth and knocked out power for over 500,000 residents. The Bahamas issued evacuation orders for its southern islands. In Haiti and the Dominican Republic, relentless rainfall caused at least four deaths.

articles.title: Ireland is riding two horses are galloping in different directions across the Atlantic
articles.author: The Irish Times
articles.summary: The Atlantic bedrock is breaking apart. The old certainties of US–European partnership are falling away under the strain of American instability. The US needs to keep the Russians out, the Americans in and the Germans down in order to keep their interests secure.

articles.title: Fonterra step-up
articles.author: Country News
articles.summary: Fonterra Oceania has announced a step-up in the farm gate milk price for its Australian suppliers. It is for the increase in the milk prices for farmers in Australia. It will be effective from January 1st, 2017.

articles.title: Rare Reptiles Ascend Mountains as Climate Heats Up
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The mountain dragon (Rankinia diemensis) is found in Victoria, New South Wales and Tasmania. It's the only native dragon lizard in Australia's east. Its range was much larger 20,000 years ago, during the peak of the last cold and dry glacial period. Its population is now very small and it's listed as a critically endangered species.

articles.title: Climate change sees 23% rise in heat-related deaths since 1990s - report
articles.author: RTE
articles.summary: There are 546,000 heat-related deaths a year due to climate change, according to the ninth Lancet Countdown Report on Health and Climate Change, published today. The rate has risen 23% since the 1990s due to the warming effects of climate change.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: what is the difference between a hurricane and a typhoon?
articles.author: David Hambling
articles.summary: Typhoons in the Pacific are bigger and more destructive than hurricanes in the Atlantic. There are about 16 typhoons a year compared to 8 hurricanes. The Pacific typhoon season runs from August to October, while the official hurricane season is from June to November.

articles.title: Climate change sees 23% rise in heat-related deaths since 1990s
articles.author: Fergal Bowers
articles.summary: The warming effects of climate change have seen the rate of heat-related deaths surge 23% since the 1990s. In 2024, air pollution from wildfire smoke was linked to a record 154,000 deaths. The global average transmission potential of dengue has risen 49% since 1950s. Air pollution resulting from the continued burning of fossil fuels has resulted in 2.5 million deaths every year. The international community is meeting at COP30 in Belem, Brazil.

articles.title: Eroding North Carolina coast swallows four MORE beachfront homes
articles.author: Jack Toledo
articles.summary: The Atlantic Ocean destroyed four vacation homes on the Outer Banks on Tuesday near Buxton on the North Carolina coast. The shoreline moved inland by 675 feet between 1980 and 2020. 26 houses on Hatteras Island have been destroyed since 2020 and two more were manually knocked down. The Outer Banks is fragile because of geography and small size and lacks protection from the ocean.

articles.title: Four beachfront homes crumble into the Atlantic as North Carolina's eroding coast devours more properties
articles.author: JACK TOLEDO
articles.summary: The Atlantic Ocean destroyed four vacation homes on the Outer Banks on Tuesday near Buxton on the North Carolina coast. The shoreline moved inland by 675 feet between 1980 and 2020. 26 houses on Hatteras Island have been destroyed since 2020 and two more were manually knocked down. The Outer Banks is fragile because of geography and small size and lacks protection from the ocean.

articles.title: Sydney's Fastest Growing Region Faces Climate Threat
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Report by Centre for Western Sydney shows that Western Sydney is one of the most at-risk and socially vulnerable to climate change in the greater Sydney area. Penrith, Hawkesbury, Blacktown, and Parramatta are among the most vulnerable communities. Fairfield, Canterbury-Bankstown, Liverpool, Cumberland, and Campbelltown are the most socially vulnerable areas in Greater Sydney.

articles.title: Topped the Climate-Adjusted Human Development Index: Kinnaur, Lahaul & Spiti, Chamba most  resilient to climate-related risks in HP
articles.author: Saurabh Parashar
articles.summary: Kinnaur, Lahaul & Spiti, and Chamba are the most resilient regions to climate-related risks in Himachal Pradesh, according to the newly released Climate-Adjusted Human Development Index (CAHDI) rankings. Solan, Bilaspur and Shimla are at the bottom of the CAHDI due to their high exposure to climate risks.

articles.title: Top Medical Journal Highlights Climate Crisis
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The 2025 Lancet Countdown on Health and Climate Change is published by The Lancet, the world's leading medical research journal. It informs government policy globally with respect to climate change. It covers 50+ indicators tracking the impacts of, and efforts to adapt to, the ongoing health effects of climate change globally. The year 2024 was the hottest on record.

articles.title: Disaster Averted at Sangam Barrage as Floodwaters Wash Away Boats
articles.author: Dc Correspondent
articles.summary: A major mishap was narrowly averted at the Sangam Barrage in Nellore district early Wednesday after three large boats used for sand excavation were washed away in the Penna River. The boats got stuck near the dam and did not collide with the barrage gates. The barrage structure remains safe, but the boats must be removed soon to avoid potential damage. The year 2024 witnessed a record 154,000 deaths attributable to airborne particulates from wildfire smoke, and vector-borne diseases are on the rise.

articles.title: Unprecedented climate crisis hit on India: Study
articles.author: New Delhi
articles.summary: India's struggle with climate change intensified dramatically in 2024. People in India were exposed to 19.8 heatwave days on average in 2024, with 6.6 days attributable directly to climate change. Wildfire smoke was responsible for an annual average of 10,200 deaths from 2020 to 2024, up 28% from 2003-2012. Anthropogenic air pollution claimed 1,718,000 lives in India in 2022, representing a 38% increase since 2010. Fossil fuels contributed to 752,000 deaths (44% of the total), with coal responsible for 394,000, mainly from power plant emissions. Petrol use in road transportation accounted for 269,000.

articles.title: Bill Gates Calls on UN to Pivot Funding From Climate to Health Care
articles.author: Rachel Roberts
articles.summary: Bill Gates wants the United Nations to make a 'major strategic pivot' from its 'doomsday view' of climate goals toward alleviating poverty and funding vaccines. Gates would let the temperature go up 0.1 degree to get rid of malaria.

articles.title: Teal MP's Push for Mandatory Climate Health Reporting via Australian CDC Rejected
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: Parliament voted down Teal MP Monique Ryan's bid to include mandatory reporting on the health effects of climate change in the soon-to-be-permanent Australian Centre for Disease Control (CDC). Ryan represents the Victorian seat of Kooyong.

articles.title: Bill Gates Cools Down on Climate
articles.author: Andrew Stuttaford
articles.summary: There is no contradiction between recognizing that anthropogenic climate change is real and rejecting the notion that it is an existential threat. Bill Gates has finally understood that there is something to all three of those points and he has just changed his mind about the steps being taken in response to it.

articles.title: LET US NOT FORGET
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: Pakistan has suffered catastrophic floods for many years. The 2010 floods inflicted an estimated US$43 billion in economic losses, resulting in years of negative growth between –2% and –5%. The 2025 floods have again exposed Pakistan's vulnerabilities, causing an estimated $2.9 billion in damages. Pakistan has failed to adopt long-term preventive measures, largely due to persistent internal and external challenges. India's alleged violation of the Indus Waters Treaty could escalate into a serious water security crisis.

articles.title: 1,400 annual deaths linked to wildfire smoke in Canada: climate and health report
articles.author: Jordan Omstead
articles.summary: The Lancet Countdown on health and climate change is considered one of the most comprehensive looks at the subject. Every year from 2020 to 2024 about 1,400 deaths in Canada were associated with wildfire smoke pollution. People in Canada last year were exposed to about six days of heat waves that would not have been expected to happen without the influence of climate change. Heat exposure last year resulted in the loss of more than 40 million potential labour hours.

articles.title: How climate change is making us sick   – DW – 10/29/2025
articles.author: Tim Schauenberg
articles.summary: The Lancet Countdown Report warns of the health consequences of climate change. The report's authors call for renewable energy, clean energy and adaptation to the climate change as the key to mitigating the risks. Last year was the warmest on record and CO2 levels in the atmosphere jumped to new highs. Heat-related deaths have surged 23% since the 1990s. Wildfire smoke was linked to 154,000 deaths in 2024, while air pollution from the burning of fossil fuels kills 2.5 million every year.

articles.title: Rising heat kills one person a minute worldwide, major report reveals
articles.author: Damian Carrington
articles.summary: Rising global heat is now killing one person a minute around the world. The world's addiction to fossil fuels also causes toxic air pollution, wildfires and the spread of diseases such as dengue fever. Governments gave out $2.5bn a day in direct subsidies to fossil fuel companies in 2023.

articles.title: Climate Inaction is Leading to Millions of Deaths Each Year
articles.author: Simmone Shah
articles.summary: The Lancet today published its 9th annual 'Countdown on Health and Climate Change' report. It aims to provide a comprehensive breakdown of the connections between climate change and health. 12 of the 20 indicators for the health risks and impacts of climate change set concerning new records. The report calls on leaders to focus on green solutions that can improve health outcomes and warns that political backsliding on climate commitments will cause more harm.

articles.title: Climate inaction ‘costing millions of lives' each year
articles.author: Lilia Sebouai
articles.summary: Millions of people are already dying because of climate change due to air pollution, extreme heat, disease and wildfire smoke. 12 out of 20 health indicators tracked by The Lancet Countdown on Health and Climate Change fell to record levels for the second consecutive year. The report also found that rising global temperatures have increased the transmission potential of dengue fever by up to 49%.

articles.summary: People in India each experienced nearly 20 heatwave days in 2024 on average, of which about six-and-a-half days would not be expected were it not for climate change. Strengthening tenant protection laws can prevent post-disaster rent spikes and evictions, and lawmakers should require landlords to make climate-resilient upgrades.
